column1: R: Thank you so much. So what did you think about the use of VR in these stories? And if you can speak to the parts that stood out to you.

P1:  Yeah, so I'll talk about school first. I think the idea of VR replacing the whole in-person experience at school is really scary. And part of it is because after living in the pandemic for two years, when we did have virtual learning, I did see negative effects with my child and like social development has been something on my radar because of that. But the use of it in terms of like a replacement of sometimes like a field trip makes sense because then learning experiences I think could be enriched and enhanced. But I don't think it replaces the total in-person experience that children should have.
R: Can you speak a little bit more about that experience, your child social development part you mentioned?

P1: Yeah, yeah. So I have found, I mean even specifically with my son right sitting next to me, that there are certain behavior in how to act in a crowd together and what is socially acceptable right now. The rules have not changed since pre-COVID, but I think the interaction amongst the kids and how they talk to each other and interact and like, what's appropriate energy level? What's not appropriate energy level? What's an appropriate use of our body and what's not?

Those things that you learn in kindergarten but because he did experience kindergarten virtually. And then I had a second son, my younger son, who was in kindergarten last year and had the full in-person experience and even the experience of sitting on a rug and listening to your teacher. It's like understanding what to do with your body while you're in the learning environment and he didn't get it as much. So to me that has really been detrimental. So it's like one example.

I even think like making friends. and being in person with friends. And it's these unsaid social things that you don't get in a virtual environment, right? And maybe they would, but that's just like my observation in having two children who kind of experience that.

And so I kind of equated a lot to like that moment when we were all trying to learn over Zoom that it's been very similar. I also think Technology in schools can be scary and concerning because I don't think that we teach children how to use it properly and I have like a child who gets distracted easily. And the line between tech time for learning and tech time for pleasure or fun is very blurred. And so we've had issues where we get off task in what we're doing. So I would imagine in the virtual reality world, the same can happen and be true. Yeah.
R: Can think of how can children and families use VR in positive or helpful ways.

P1: Yeah, um...So you know right now I see it as like a way to spend time. I don't know, like families. I don't know. To me it's like a replacement for like video games, which I'm not opposed to video games. They're fun. You can have connection with them too. It's a certain kind of connection. And I don't think there's anything wrong with getting wrapped up in a story and an experience.

But it's not understanding human connection in a nuanced way. You know? So you're still talking about the problems and issues around. Yeah. And I know I guess, yeah, I don't think it's a bad thing, but it's all about moderation, right? But it's just another thing that parents now have to really focus on and kind of like be responsible for the teaching of which is just one more you know they're just I don't know.

R: I know that you kind of mentioned some pieces of problems that you foresee using VR but is there other kinds of problems that might VR create for children and family that you haven't mentioned or spoken about?

P1: The nuanced human connection, I kind of said. I think the distractability and transitions. Like I think with young kids, transitions are really hard and like the start and stop is always tricky. Like I think something that could help would be, and VR probably has this, Oculus probably has this, but like timers.

We find that extremely helpful where it's like, okay, the experience just shuts off and it's time for it to be done, right? And so it's like those transitions can be tricky and I would imagine in VR, that's also the case, right? Because you're completely immersed. Even as an adult, you're like, okay, it's time to stop. You're like, okay, we gotta stop now, right? Yeah, who should decide which VR experiences are suitable for kids? Yeah, oh.

That's really tricky and I don't even think it's a black and white answer because I have a lot of trust in our education system, but I also know that like, I also question, it's a spectrum right? And I don't know, I feel like there needs to be more data behind the research to inform a little more and not just as strict as like the American pediatric because I….I have a lot of trust in that body, but sometimes I don't feel like it's aligned with reality and what parents actually experience. So it's kind of like both. It's like we need to find information from all sources, whether it be education, kind of science-backed information, and then parents at the end of the day have to kind of make that choice on their own, but have some data to back up their choices.

And then within schools, I mean, I don't know. I don't even know if I have the answer. I don't even know, right? But I know if I saw something and I'd be like, this feels concerning, I'd maybe say something, but at the end of the day it's not a perfect system. Right, right. You know?
